title.value: Improving and Generalizing Flow-Based Generative Models with Minibatch Optimal Transport
title.justification: This is the title given in the paper's header.
title.quote: Improving and Generalizing Flow-Based Generative Models with Minibatch Optimal Transport

extractions.description: This research paper introduces the generalized conditional flow matching (CFM) technique for continuous normalizing flows (CNFs). This method provides a simulation-free training procedure for CNFs, which is more stable and efficient than previous methods. Additionally, it presents a variant called optimal transport CFM (OT-CFM) which improves training stability and inference speed by approximating dynamic optimal transport. The paper also includes empirical evaluations on tasks such as single-cell dynamics, unsupervised image translation, and Schrödinger bridge inference.

type.justification: The paper involves empirical evaluation on single-cell dynamics, unsupervised image translation, and Schrödinger bridge inference, indicating that it is an empirical study.
type.quote: We evaluate CFM and OT-CFM in experiments on single-cell dynamics, image generation, unsupervised image translation, and energy-based models.

name.justification: The paper focuses on improving and generalizing flow-based generative models, indicating its primary relevance to the field of Generative Modeling.
name.quote: Improving and Generalizing Flow-Based Generative Models

name.justification: The paper presents a variant called optimal transport CFM which links it to the field of Optimal Transport.
name.quote: A variant of our objective is optimal transport CFM (OT-CFM), which creates simpler flows that are more stable to train and lead to faster inference, as evaluated in our experiments.

name.justification: The paper includes empirical evaluation on Schrödinger bridge inference, indicating its relevance to this sub-field.
CFM is one of the main methods introduced in the paper to provide a simulation-free training procedure for continuous normalizing flows.
name.quote: We introduce the generalized conditional flow matching (CFM) technique, a family of simulation-free training objectives for CNFs.

is_contributed.justification: The CFM model is introduced and explored within this paper.
is_contributed.quote: We introduce the generalized conditional flow matching (CFM) technique, a family of simulation-free training objectives for CNFs.

is_executed.justification: This model was executed and evaluated in the scope of the paper.
is_executed.quote: We evaluate CFM and OT-CFM in experiments on single-cell dynamics, image generation, unsupervised image translation, and energy-based models.

is_compared.justification: CFM model's performance is compared against other models in different tasks.
is_compared.quote: We evaluate CFM and OT-CFM in experiments on single-cell dynamics, image generation, unsupervised image translation, and energy-based models.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The CFM model introduced in this paper builds on concepts from this prior work.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We introduce the generalized conditional flow matching (CFM) technique, a family of simulation-free training objectives for CNFs. CFM features a stable regression objective like that used to train the stochastic flow in diffusion models but enjoys the efficient inference of deterministic flow models.

name.justification: OT-CFM is introduced as a variant of CFM that approximates dynamic optimal transport and is designed to be more stable to train and to allow faster inference.
name.quote: A variant of our objective is optimal transport CFM (OT-CFM), which creates simpler flows that are more stable to train and lead to faster inference, as evaluated in our experiments.

is_contributed.justification: OT-CFM is introduced as a new contribution in this paper.
is_contributed.quote: A variant of our objective is optimal transport CFM (OT-CFM), which creates simpler flows that are more stable to train and lead to faster inference, as evaluated in our experiments.

is_executed.justification: This model was trained and evaluated within the study.
is_executed.quote: We evaluate CFM and OT-CFM in experiments on single-cell dynamics, image generation, unsupervised image translation, and energy-based models.

is_compared.justification: OT-CFM's performance is compared to other models in the conducted experiments.
is_compared.quote: We evaluate CFM and OT-CFM in experiments on single-cell dynamics, image generation, unsupervised image translation, and energy-based models.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The OT-CFM model builds on the concepts of CFM described in this paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: A variant of our objective is optimal transport CFM (OT-CFM), which creates simpler flows that are more stable to train and lead to faster inference, as evaluated in our experiments.

name.justification: CIFAR-10 dataset is used for high-dimensional image generation evaluation.
name.quote: We perform an experiment on unconditional CIFAR-10 generation from a Gaussian source to examine how OT-CFM performs in the high-dimensional image setting.

referenced_paper_title.value: Learning Multiple Layers of Features from Tiny Images
referenced_paper_title.justification: This is the primary reference paper for the CIFAR-10 dataset.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Learning Multiple Layers of Features from Tiny Images

name.justification: CelebA dataset is used for unsupervised image translation tasks.
name.quote: We show how CFM can be used to learn a mapping between two unpaired datasets in high-dimensional space using the CelebA dataset (Liu et al., 2015; Sun et al., 2014), which consists of ∼ 200k images of faces together with 40 binary attribute annotations.

referenced_paper_title.value: Deep Learning Face Attributes in the Wild
referenced_paper_title.justification: This is the primary reference paper for the CelebA dataset.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Deep Learning Face Attributes in the Wild

name.justification: CITE-seq dataset is used in the evaluation of single-cell dynamics.
name.quote: We also include the Embryoid body data from Moon et al. (2019); Tong et al. (2020).

name.quote: The architecture is implemented in PyTorch (Paszke et al., 2019).
